Inverse ZrO₂/Ni catalysts promoted with Y, La, Sr, and Pr were synthesized and evaluated for CO₂ methanation. The impact of these promoters on the structure, properties, and catalytic performance of inverse ZrO₂/Ni catalyst was systematically investigated. A comprehensive suite of characterization techniques, including XRD, BET, H₂-TPR, CO₂-TPD, TEM, HRTEM, EDX-Mapping, and quasi in-situ XPS, was employed to elucidate the relationship between the physicochemical properties of the catalysts and their CO₂ methanation catalytic performance. 5Y65Zr/30Ni catalyst exhibited superior methanation activity compared with other catalysts, which was correlated with its enhanced specific surface area, a high concentration of medium basic sites facilitating CO₂ adsorption and activation, a high surface oxygen ratio, and optimal Ni dispersion achieved through minimized Ni crystallite size. These findings demonstrated that the strategic incorporation of promoters allowed for precise tailoring of inverse ZrO₂/Ni catalyst properties, providing valuable insights for the rational design of highly efficient CO₂ methanation catalysts. Graphical abstract Keywords Methanation Inverse catalyst promoter effects Synergistic effect Structure-activity relationships Data availability The data that has been used is confidential. 1 Introduction The increasing concentration of carbon dioxide (CO2) in the atmosphere has emerged as a paramount issue, because of escalating environmental concerns and increased greenhouse effect [1,2]. Facing this problem and transitioning towards a sustainable, carbon-neutral energy economy all require innovative strategies for CO₂ capture and utilization [3,4]. CO₂ capture needs high energy demands and costs, which limits its practical application. In contrast, CO2 utilization and conversion technologies spurred extensive research [5]. CO₂ is capable of undergoing catalytic transformation into a wide array of value-added chemical products, with particular emphasis on the generation of methane (CH4). CO2 methanation reaction, also called Sabatier reaction (CO2 + 4H2 → CH4 + 2H2O, ΔHr°298k = −165kJ/mol), represents a promising route to close the carbon cycle while leveraging renewable hydrogen from electrolysis of water using renewable energy [6,7]. However, the kinetic and thermodynamic challenges of CO₂ activation necessitate the development of high-performance catalysts that balance activity, selectivity, and stability under mild conditions for large-scale implementation [8,9]. Compared with noble metal catalysts, Ni-based catalysts have been widely employed in CO2 methanation due to their low cost and high availability [10,11]. Traditional methanation catalysts typically consist of nickel nanoparticles dispersed on high-surface-area oxide supports such as Al2O3, SiO2 and ZrO2 [12–14]. It is worthy to note that promoters are usually used to improve the catalytic stability, reducibility, active phase dispersion and modulate metal-support interactions [15,16]. Many studies have focused on finding high quality promoters to obtain excellent catalytic performance during CO2 methanation [17]. For example, Tsiotsias et al. [18] explored the effect of Pr doping on Ni/CeO2 for CO2 methanation reaction and found Pr3+ ions can substitute Ce4+ ones in the support lattice, thereby introducing the formation of oxygen vacancies, which were beneficial for CO2 adsorption. Ullah et al. [19] investigated La doped Ni-CeO2 catalysts for CO2 methanation and found La as a dopant reduced particle size of Ni, promoted Ni dispersion, and increased interfacial sites. Siakavelas et al. [20] also investigated the effect of different promoters (Sm2O3, Pr2O3 or MgO) on Ni/CeO2 catalysts in CO2 methanation reaction. Sun et al. [21] synthesized different content of Y promoted Ni/SBA-16 catalysts for CO2 methanation, and found 10wt% Y promoted catalyst exhibited the best catalytic performance, which was attributed to the increase of reducibility of nickel species, more surface oxygen species, and medium basic sites caused by Y promotion. The traditional support-active metal relationship is reversed in an inverse catalyst, which can enhance metal-support interfacial sites [22]. An inverse ZnO/Co structure with plentiful uniformly dispersed active sites was used for CO2 methanation and achieved CO2 conversion of 62.9%, CH4 selectivity of 99.2% at 300 ℃ [23]. Tian et al. [24] synthesized a series of inverse CeO2-Cr2O3/Ni catalysts and investigated the role of oxide-metal interfaces in CO₂ methanation performance. Compared to Ni/CeO2 catalysts, inverse CeO2/Ni catalysts with abundant Ni-CeO2 interfaces showed much better activity and stability for CO2 hydrogenation to methane, enabling efficient low temperature catalytic performance [25]. ZrO₂ as support offers exceptional thermal and chemical stability along with tunable redox properties, making it ideal for sustained CO₂ methanation [26–28]. Zhang et al. [11] compared Ni/ZrO₂ catalysts prepared by different methods and revealed that Ni/ZrO₂ nanofibers via electrospinning exhibited superior catalytic activity due to high surface area and abundant oxygen vacancies. The effect of calcination and reduction treatment of Ni/ZrO2 catalysts on the structure and catalytic activity was also investigated [26]. CaZrO3 on Ni-CaZrO3 catalyst reduced the particle size of Ni nanoparticles and enhanced the activity for CO2 methanation [29]. On basis this, inverse ZrO2 /Ni catalyst also have shown great potential in the field of CO2 methanation. Song et al. [30] reported CeZrOx/Ni inverse catalyst exhibited high low-temperature activity for CO2 methanation. The current studies are less concerned with the CO2 methanation reaction on inverse ZrO2/Ni catalysts. In addition, the electronic and structural properties of ZrO2 /Ni catalysts could be further improved by the introduction of appropriate promoters such as rare-earth or alkaline-earth metals, and further optimize the performance of ZrO2 /Ni in CO2 methanation. The comprehensive comparison of the effects of multiple promoters on the ZrO2/Ni catalysts is still under study and deserve further exploration. In this work, we focused on synthesizing a series of inverse ZrO₂/Ni catalysts promoted by Y, La, Sr, and Pr and systematically investigating the impact of different promoters on the structure, surface properties, and CO₂ methanation activity of different inverse ZrO₂/Ni catalysts. A series of characterization techniques, including X-ray diffraction (XRD), Brunauer-Emmett-Teller (BET) surface area analysis, H₂-temperature programmed reduction (H₂-TPR), CO₂-temperature programmed desorption (CO₂-TPD), transmission electron microscopy (TEM), high-resolution transmission electron microscopy (HRTEM), energy-dispersive X-ray (EDX) mapping, and quasi in-situ X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (quasi in-situ XPS), were employed to comprehensively elucidate the relationship between the physicochemical properties of these catalysts and their catalytic performance. 2 Experimental section 2.1 Synthesis of catalysts The NiO support was prepared by direct calcination of Ni(NO₃)₂·6H₂O at 500 °C for 4h in air with a heating rate of 10°C/min. The composition (5% promoter/65% Zr/30% Ni) was selected based on our prior systematic optimization of Zr/Ni ratios for CO₂ methanation, where 70ZrO2/30Ni demonstrated optimal activity [31]. In this study, we introduced promoters (Y, La, Sr, Pr) at a fixed low loading (5%) to isolate their individual effects while maintaining the previously optimized Zr/Ni backbone. A series of promoted inverse Zr/Ni catalysts were synthesized using the co-impregnation method. Taking 5Y65Zr/30Ni catalyst as an example, predetermined amounts of Y(NO₃)₃·6H₂O and ZrO(NO₃)₂·xH₂O were dissolved in deionized water under stirring until a homogeneous solution was obtained. Subsequently, the NiO support was added to the solution, and the mixture was stirred continuously at room temperature for 24h. Following impregnation, the excess solvent was removed by rotary evaporation at 90 °C. The resulting solid was then dried in an oven at 95 °C for 6h to remove any residual water. Finally, the dried powder was calcined at 500 °C for 4h (10°C/min ramp rate) in air to obtain 5Y65Zr/30Ni catalyst. The un-promoted 70Zr/30Ni catalysts were prepared using the same process, and the other additive catalysts were prepared by replacing with the corresponding La(NO₃)₃-6H₂O, Sr(NO₃)2 and Pr(NO₃)₃-6H₂O, and other processes were the same, and the prepared catalysts were noted as 70Zr/30Ni, 5Y65Zr/30Ni, 5La65Zr/30Ni, 5Sr65Zr/30Ni and 5Pr65Zr/30Ni. 2.2 Catalyst characterization The physical properties of the catalysts were evaluated by nitrogen adsorption-desorption isotherms (BET) by using a Belsorp Mini II apparatus (BEL Japan) instrument. Prior to measurement, the catalysts were degassed under vacuum condition at 200 ℃ for 2h. The adsorption-desorption tests were conducted at -196 ℃. The specific surface area of the catalysts was calculated via the Brunauer-Emmett-Teller (BET) method, and the pore volume and pore size distribution were derived from the Barrett- Joyner-Halenda (BJH) method. The crystal structure of catalysts was analyzed by X-ray diffraction (XRD) measurements using a DX-1000 CSC diffractometer with a Cu Kα radiation source. The anode current and voltage were 25mA and 40kV, respectively. The diffraction patterns were recorded in a 2θ range of 10° to 80°, with a scan step size of 0.03° and a scan rate of 0.3s step-1. The particle size was calculated using the Scherrer Equation. The reducibility of catalysts was assessed through temperature-programmed reduction of H2 (H2-TPR) on a BELCAT-M (BEL Japan, BEL Europe GmbH, Krefeld, Germany) apparatus equipped with a thermal conductivity detector (TCD). The calcined catalysts were pretreated under helium at 110 °C for 1h. Then the catalysts were reduced under 5% H2/Ar mixture flow and heated to 800 ℃ with a heating rate of 10 ℃/min and held on 30min at 800 ℃. The data were collected from 50 to 800 ℃. The basicity of catalysts was measured via the temperature-programmed desorption of CO2 (CO2-TPD) on the same equipment. The catalysts were reduced at 550 ℃ under a 5% H2/Ar flow for 1h, followed by CO2 adsorption at 50 °C for 1h under a mixture flow of 10% CO2/ He. Afterward, the weakly adsorbed CO2 was removed by helium purge for 30min. Last, the catalysts were heated to 800 ℃ (10 ℃/min) under a He flow. The data were collected from 50 to 800 ℃. X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) was performed using an AXIS Ultra DLD (KRA TOS) spectrometer with a monochromatic Al Kα source at 15kV and 10mA, acquiring spectra in 0.05eV increments. The reduced catalyst was analyzed for quasi in situ XPS. The sample was reduced at 550 ℃ and transferred directly into an XPS vacuum chamber to avoid oxidation due to exposure to air. The fitting was performed using the CasaXPS Software using a Shirley background subtraction and a Gaussian-Lorentzian peak shape for all spectra. The spectra were charge-corrected to the C 1s peak at 284.6eV. The peak positions and full width at half maximum (FWHM) were carefully determined based on literature values and by minimizing the residuals during the fitting process. The calculation of the concentration of surface oxygen atoms per mass of catalyst (CO,mass) is reported in supporting information from XPS results. The morphology and elemental distribution of catalysts were examined by transmission electron microscopy (TEM) and energy-dispersive X-ray (EDX) mapping using an FEI Tecnai G2 20 Twin instrument with an acceleration voltage of 200kV. 2.3 Catalyst evaluation The catalytic activity test was evaluated in a fixed-bed flow microreactor (inner diameter 10mm) with a temperature range from 200 °C to 450 °C by temperature steps after reaching the steady state. A Type K thermocouple was positioned near the catalytic bed to monitor the reaction temperature throughout the experiment. Prior to CO₂ methanation reaction, the catalysts were pre-reduced at 550 °C for 1h in 5vol% H₂/Ar stream. The total reactant gas flow rate was maintained at 100mL/min with a molar composition of H₂/CO₂/Ar = 12/3/5. The total gas hourly space velocity (GHSV) was 40,000h⁻¹. The effluent gases were analyzed using a gas chromatograph equipped with a thermal conductivity detector (TCD) to determine the composition of the products. For time-on-stream tests, the same reactant gas mixture was introduced through the catalytic bed, which was held at the target temperature for the duration of the test. CO2 conversion and CH4 selectivity were calculated by the following equations: (1) X C O 2 = n C O 2 , in − n C O 2 , out n C O 2 , in × 100 % = % CO 2 in * Q in − % CO 2 out * Q out % CO 2 in * Q in × 100 % , (2) S C H 4 = n C H 4 , out n C H 4 , out + n CO , out × 100 % = % CH 4 o ut * Q o ut % CH 4 o ut * Q o ut + % CO o ut * Q o ut × 100 % , Where XCO2 represents the conversion of CO2, SCH4 is the selectivity of CH4. n C O 2 , in and n C O 2 , out refer to the molar concentration of CO2 in inlet and outlet, respectively. n C H 4 , out and n CO , out represent the molar concentration of CH4 and CO in outlet, respectively. Qin and Qout represent the inlet and outlet volumetric flow fed respectively. The mass balance is also calculated to ensure that the calculations are reliable. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Catalytic performance in CO2 methanation The catalytic performance of different catalysts for CO₂ methanation was systematically evaluated, and the results were presented in Fig.1. CO₂ conversion and CH₄ selectivity were measured over a temperature range of 200 °C to 450 °C. These error bars represent the standard deviation of three independent experiments, providing a clear indication of the reproducibility of the catalytic activity data. As depicted in Fig.1(A), CO₂ conversion increased steadily with increasing temperature for all catalysts. The addition of Y and La into 70Zr/30Ni catalyst significantly enhanced CO2 conversion, particularly at lower temperatures, suggesting improved catalytic activity. In contrast, the addition of Pr and Sr resulted in decreased conversion especially at elevated temperatures, indicating a potential negative impact on catalytic efficiency of Zr/Ni catalyst. Among these catalysts, 5Y65Zr/30Ni catalyst exhibited the highest CO₂ conversion across the entire temperature range, reaching approximately 68% conversion at 250 °C. 5La65Zr/30Ni and 5Pr65Zr/30Ni catalysts demonstrated intermediate performance with CO₂ conversions around 62% and 57%, respectively, at the same temperature. The unpromoted 70Zr/30Ni catalyst showed comparatively lower activity compared to the promoted ones with 31% CO2 conversion at 250 °C. While 5Sr65Zr/30Ni catalyst exhibited the lowest conversion among these catalysts, only 16% CO2 conversion at the same temperature. Fig.1 (B) illustrated CH₄ selectivity of different catalysts. Notably, all the catalysts maintained a remarkably high CH₄ selectivity (>95%) throughout the investigated temperature range. This indicated that the methanation pathway predominates on these catalysts, with minimal generation of byproducts such as CO. The time-on-stream (TOS) stability tests for 5Y65Zr/30Ni catalyst was evaluated at 250 °C and 300 °C under H₂/CO₂ (4:1 molar ratio). As shown in Fig.2 (A) and (B), 5Y65Zr/30Ni retained ~63% CO₂ conversion at 250 °C and ~81% at 300 °C over 24h. The CH4 selectivity was consistently near 100% throughout the entire stability test, and 5Y65Zr/30Ni catalyst exhibited good stability and minimal deactivation during the process of operation, indicating good stability under these conditions. 3.2 Specific surface area measurements by BET experiments Nitrogen adsorption-desorption measurements were performed to characterize the textural properties of different catalysts, and the results were summarized in Table 1 and Fig.3. All catalysts displayed type IV isotherms with H3 hysteresis loops. A clear correlation between specific surface area and catalytic activity was observed. The incorporation of Y and La resulted in a significant enhancement of specific surface area compared to the unpromoted 70Zr/30Ni catalyst (45.7m²/g). 5Y65Zr/30Ni catalyst showed the highest specific surface area (66.5m²/g), closely followed by 5La65Zr/30Ni (65.8m²/g). This enhancement in specific surface area likely contributed to the improved CO₂ conversion observed for these catalysts, providing a greater number of active sites for reactant adsorption and reaction. 5Pr65Zr/30Ni catalyst also demonstrated a relatively high specific surface area (63.2m²/g) and correspondingly good catalytic performance, further supporting this correlation. Conversely, the 5Sr65Zr/30Ni catalyst showed a lower specific surface area (48.8m²/g), which could explain its comparatively lower CO₂ conversion. Nonetheless, it is important to recognize that specific surface area is not the sole determinant of catalytic behavior. Other factors, such as metal-support interactions, Ni dispersion, and the nature of active sites, also play significant roles. This is exemplified by the observation that the 5Pr65Zr/30Ni catalyst, despite having a slightly lower specific surface area than the La-promoted catalyst, displays comparable activity. The addition of promoters generally reduced the pore size of catalysts compared to the unpromoted catalyst, suggesting that the smaller pores do not impose significant mass transport limitations on the CO₂ methanation reaction under the tested conditions. Furthermore, pore volume trends paralleled those of specific surface area, with the Y-promoted catalyst possessing the largest pore volume (0.135cm³/g) and the Sr-promoted catalyst the smallest (0.087cm³/g). This underscored the pronounced effect of Y promotion in enhancing the textural features of the inverse 70Zr/30Ni catalyst, thereby benefiting CO₂ methanation. Similar properties of Y promotion were already found on double layered Ni-based catalysts promoted with Y for CO2 methanation [32]. 3.3 Evaluation of the Ni and ZrO2 phases and their respective particle size by XRD To elucidate the effects of different promoters (Y, La, Sr, and Pr) on the inverse Zr/Ni crystal structure and stability, XRD analysis was conducted to characterize the crystalline structure and phase composition of different catalysts. The XRD patterns of different catalysts both after reduction and CO₂ methanation reaction were presented in Fig.4. All reduced catalysts displayed the characteristic diffraction peaks corresponding to metallic Ni (PDF#04-0850) and tetragonal ZrO₂ (t-ZrO₂, PDF#50-1089). No distinct diffraction peaks associated with promoter Y, La, Sr, or Pr species were detected, implying that these promoters were either highly dispersed on the catalyst surface or existed in an amorphous form. Importantly, the stability of the t-ZrO₂ phase was preserved across all promoted catalysts. Notably, the addition of promoters led to a broadening of Ni diffraction peaks, indicative of reduced Ni crystallite sizes, as corroborated by the quantitative estimates in Table 2. The reduced particle size resulted from the increased surface area by adding promoters [33]. The XRD patterns of the fresh catalysts (Fig. S1) exhibit diffraction peaks corresponding to NiO, indicating the presence of NiO crystallites in all samples. The average crystallite sizes of both ZrO₂ and Ni species were calculated using the Scherrer equation, and the results were summarized in Table 2. The average NiO crystallite sizes were also calculated and were summarized in Table S1. The adding of promoters decreased the particle sizes of NiO, with 5Y65Zr/30Ni exhibiting the smallest crystallites (20.5nm), consistent with its superior Ni dispersion and catalytic activity. The unpromoted reduced Zr/Ni catalyst exhibited the largest Ni crystallite size (25.7nm) compared to the other promoted catalysts. 5Y65Zr/30Ni catalyst showed the smallest Ni crystallites (22.2nm) and simultaneously displayed the highest CO₂ methanation activity. This inverse relationship between Ni particle size and catalytic performance underscored the critical role of Ni dispersion, as smaller crystallites yield higher surface area and more active sites. After CO₂ methanation reaction, the XRD patterns of all post-reaction catalysts in Fig.4 (B) revealed that characteristic peaks of both ZrO₂ and metallic Ni were largely retained, confirming phase stability during catalysis. However, comparing the crystallite sizes before and after the reaction (Table 2), it was evident that Ni crystallite size of all catalysts increased, indicating some degree of Ni sintering under reaction conditions. Among all catalysts, the 5Y65Zr/30Ni catalyst demonstrated superior resistance to sintering, exhibiting relatively stable Ni crystallite size. The Y-promoted catalyst maintained small and stable Ni nanoparticles and thus strongly correlated with its enhanced CO₂ methanation activity. This higher activity can be attributed to the larger active surface area provided by the smaller Ni crystallites throughout the reaction. 3.4 Study of the reducibility of the promoted inverse catalysts The reducibility of the Zr/Ni catalysts modified with various promoters (Y, La, Sr, and Pr) was investigated by H₂-TPR experiments. The H2-TPR profiles of all catalysts were deconvoluted into three distinct reduction peaks, suggesting that the catalyst possessed a variety of NiO species exhibiting differing degrees of metal-support interaction and reducibility, as shown in Fig.5. For the unpromoted 70Zr/30Ni catalyst, the reduction peak centered at 357 °C corresponds to the reduction of NiO with weak metal-support interaction, signifying a higher degree of dispersion and smaller NiO crystallite size [34]. The peaks observed around 417 °C are attributed to the reduction of NiO with medium strength metal-support interaction, while the peaks near 504 °C are associated with the reduction of NiO with strong metal-support interaction [35,36]. The introduction of different promoters notably altered the reduction behavior of the catalysts. The addition of promoters shifted these reduction peaks to higher temperatures relative to the unpromoted 70Zr/30Ni catalyst, suggesting a stronger NiO-ZrO₂ interaction in the promoted catalysts. Quantitative analysis of H₂ consumption derived from the integrated peak areas was summarized in Table 2. The incorporation of different promoters led to an increasing of H2 consumption, which could be attributed to the promoted nickel reduction. Among the promoted catalysts, 5Y65Zr/30Ni exhibited the highest proportion of NiO species with weak metal-support interaction, implying superior Ni dispersion and enhanced reducibility, which are factors closely linked to improved catalytic performance. 3.5 Influence of the promoters on the catalyst’s basicity CO₂-TPD experiments were conducted to investigate the influence of the Y, La, Sr, and Pr promoters on the surface basic sites of the Zr/Ni catalysts. As depicted in Fig. 6, the TPD profiles was deconvoluted into the multiple CO₂ desorption peaks corresponding to basic sites of varying strengths: weak basic sites (desorption < 200 °C), medium basic sites (desorption between 200-400°C), and strong basic sites (desorption > 400 °C) [37]. For the purposes of quantitative analysis, the CO₂ uptake (mmol /g) for total basic sites and different basic sites was calculated, and the results were shown in Table 3. Compared to the unpromoted 70Zr/30Ni catalyst, the addition of different promoters all increased the number of basic sites on the catalysts. Notably, the 5La65Zr/30Ni catalyst exhibited the highest total basic site concentration (30.9mmol/g), predominantly attributed to an increased population of strong basic sites. Conversely, the 5Y65Zr/30Ni catalyst possessed the greatest number and relative proportion of medium basic sites, which correlates strongly with its enhanced catalytic performance. Makolkin et al. [38] also confirmed that Y as an effective promoter for Ni catalysts to increase the number of medium basic sites. Medium basic sites play a critical role in facilitating CO₂ adsorption and activation, thereby effectively promoting the methanation reaction [39]. 3.6 Morphology and elemental distribution of 70Zr/30Ni and 5Y65Zr/30Ni The morphology of the unpromoted 70Zr/30Ni and Y-promoted 5Y65Zr/30Ni catalysts after reduction and reaction was explored by TEM and HRTEM, which are presented in Fig.7, offering detailed insights into their structural characteristics. 70Zr/30Ni catalyst exhibited a heterogeneous morphology with agglomerated particles of varying sizes. The particles appear to be loosely interconnected, forming a porous network. In contrast, 5Y65Zr/30Ni catalyst displayed a more homogeneous morphology with finely dispersed particles, indicating that Y promotion effectively inhibits particle agglomeration and enhances the dispersion of Ni and ZrO₂ phases. This improvement of the dispersion was likely due to the enhanced interaction between the Ni species and the ZrO₂ mediated by Y, corroborated by H₂-TPR analysis. Similar phenomena have been reported in Ni/CeO₂ catalysts, where Y promotion results in smaller, highly dispersed Ni particles relative to the unpromoted counterpart [40]. The lattice spacings of 0.204nm and 0.295nm, corresponded to the (111) crystal plane of Ni and (011) crystal plane of t-ZrO₂, respectively, which can be found on both 70Zr/30Ni and 5Y65Zr/30Ni in Fig.6 (C) and (D). It is clear to observe the Ni-ZrO₂ interfacial structure on the catalysts. The elemental distribution of 70Zr/30Ni and 5Y65Zr/30Ni catalysts were further investigated by EDX-mapping, as shown in Fig.8. In Fig.8 (A), 70Zr/30Ni catalyst showed an agglomerated structure with Zr and O maps indicating a homogeneous distribution consistent with a uniform ZrO₂ phase. The Ni map reveals the presence of larger, distinct Ni particles dispersed. These Ni particles appeared somewhat segregated and non-uniformly distributed on the nanoscale. Fig.8(B) confirmed the presence and spatial distribution of Zr, Ni, and Y elements on 5Y65Zr/30Ni catalyst. Compared to 70Zr/30Ni, 5Y65Zr/30Ni showed a slightly less dense structure, with Zr and O maps maintaining a relatively uniform distribution, suggesting preservation of the ZrO₂ structure. Y was also uniformly dispersed, which indicated that it has been successfully incorporated into the catalyst structure. Crucially, the Ni mapping revealed markedly enhanced Ni dispersion compared to 70Zr/30Ni. This observation was consistent with the previous finding that the Y-promoted catalyst exhibited a higher surface area and smaller Ni particle size, which improved the catalytic activity for CO2 methanation. 3.7 Surface composition of the promoted inverse catalysts The surface elements composition and oxidation states on the catalysts surface were analyzed by X ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS). Fig. 9 presented the XPS spectra of (a) Ni 2p, (b) O 1s, and (c) Zr 3d on different catalysts. The Ni 2p spectra of the catalysts showed multiple peaks corresponding to different oxidation states of nickel. The peak near 852eV is assigned to metallic nickel (Ni0), while peaks at slightly higher binding energies correspond to Ni²⁺ species. Additionally, the satellite peak of Ni²⁺ appeared around 860eV [41,42].As summarized in Table 4, 5Y65Zr/30Ni, 5La65Zr/30Ni, and 5Pr65Zr/30Ni catalysts exhibited relatively high Ni0 ratios of 34.17%, 36.79%, and 33.49%, respectively. This observation was consistent with their higher CO₂ methanation catalytic activity, as metallic nickel was the active site for CO₂ hydrogenation. The Zr 3d spectra (Fig. 9B) was deconvoluted into four peaks attributed to Zr 3d3/2 and Zr 3d5/2 spin-orbit components [43]. The peaks around 181eV and 183eV corresponded to Zr3+ species, while the peaks around 182eV and 184eV were associated with Zr4+ species [44]. Quantitative analysis indicated that promoter addition reduced the relative amount of Zr³⁺, implying a modification of the electronic structure of ZrO₂ induced by these promoters. The O 1s spectra can be deconvoluted into peaks corresponding to different oxygen species, including lattice oxygen (Olat at 529eV), surface oxygen (Osur at 530eV), and the surface-adsorbed oxygen (Oads at 533eV) [45,46]. The proportion of surface oxygen was calculated, as higher surface oxygen concentrations were known to enhance CO₂ activation, thereby promoting the initial steps of the methanation reaction [47]. The surface oxygen concentration per mass of catalyst using the specific surface area and the surface oxygen ratio for each catalyst was also calculated. Notably, 5Y65Zr/30Ni exhibited a dominant surface oxygen content of 76.17%, compared to 62.43% for the unpromoted catalyst. Compared with 70Zr/30Ni catalyst, the addition of different promoters increased surface oxygen content on the catalyst. 5Y65Zr/30Ni catalyst also displayed the highest surface oxygen concentration per mass, which exhibited the highest catalytic activity. Other promoters similarly induced moderate increases in surface oxygen species and the surface oxygen concentration, likely facilitating the formation of oxygen vacancies that improve CO₂ adsorption and activation. 4 Structure-activity discussion Establishing a clear relationship between catalyst structure and catalytic activity is a significant challenge in heterogeneous catalysis. CO2 methanation is a complex reaction influenced by multiple factors, including surface area, active site dispersion, the presence of specific surface oxygen species, and the abundance of basic sites. This section explores the interplay of these physicochemical properties in the Y, La, Sr, and Pr promoted Zr/Ni catalysts, as shown in Fig.10. The Fig.10 (A) presented the relationship between the CO2 conversion at 250 °C of different promoted Zr/Ni catalysts and their specific surface area, and the surface oxygen ratio of the studied catalysts. The Fig.10 (B) presented the relationship between the catalytic activity at 250 °C and their Ni0 particle size, and the total number of medium basic sites of the studied catalysts. As shown in Fig. 10, all the promoted catalysts showed higher CO2 conversion except 5Sr65Zr/30Ni catalyst. Among them, the higher conversion is found for Y promoted catalysts (68% of CO2 conversion), followed by La and Pr. Y, La are reported to be efficient promoters for CO2 methanation [32,45,48]. 5Y65Zr/30Ni catalyst exhibited the highest surface oxygen concentration depicted in Fig. 10 (A), which was benefit for CO2 methanation. The presence of surface oxygen species could facilitate the formation of oxygen vacancies, particularly oxygen vacancies adjacent to Ni sites, were believed to facilitate CO2 dissociation – a rate-determining step in the methanation mechanism and promote C-O bond cleavage [49]. The higher concentration of these sites on the Y-promoted catalyst facilitated the initial activation of the relatively stable CO₂ molecule. The surface concentration of oxygen per mass of catalyst calculated by using the specific surface area and surface oxygen ratio also confirmed it. 5Y65Zr/30Ni catalyst also displayed the highest surface oxygen concentration per mass. 5Y65Zr/30Ni also showed a slightly higher specific surface area compared to those with the other promoters. In contrast, the unpromoted 70Zr/30Ni exhibited the lowest surface area. The enhanced surface area facilitated higher CO₂ conversion by providing more accessible active sites for the reaction and Ni species reduction, while the high surface oxygen concentration facilities CO₂ conversion to CH₄ due to the formation of oxygen vacancies. 5Y65Zr/30Ni presented a smaller Ni particle size (22.2nm prior reaction, and 22.9nm after reaction), suggesting that Y promoted the dispersion of Ni particles and increased the availability of active sites, leading to a higher reaction rate. The high catalytic performance of Ni/3Y-Ce-Ox for CO2 methanation because of the increased reducibility and reduced Ni size also proved this [40]. In contrast, the unpromoted 70Zr/30Ni and 5Sr65Zr/30Ni exhibited the largest Ni particle sizes, indicating a less dispersed Ni phase. While the effect of smaller Ni particle size alone was not dramatic, it contributed to the overall enhanced activity in conjunction with the other properties. Finally, when considering the importance of the basicity, 5Y65Zr/30Ni also exhibited the highest concentration of medium basic sites as revealed by CO₂-TPD, which could promote the CO₂ adsorption and activation. On the contrary, the La-promoted and Pr-promoted catalysts (La, Pr) were located in the middle region, and they also displayed the CO2 conversion in the middle region. Similar studies have also emphasized the critical role of medium basic sites. Xu et al. [22] found the increasing of the weak and medium CO2 adsorption sites on ZrZnOx/Cu inverse catalyst improved the methanol productivity. Wang et al. [50] also found the more medium basic sites on CaH2 promoted Ni/CaCO3 were favorable for the activation of CO2, and further improved CO2 methanation. The relationship between a catalyst's physicochemical properties and its performance is often complex and multifactorial. Fig.10 illustrates this multifaceted relationship. These structure-reactivity correlations highlight the importance of optimizing multiple physicochemical properties such as particle size, basicity, oxygen surface species and specific surface area to achieve high CO₂ methanation activity. Y-promoted catalyst (5Y65Zr/30Ni) demonstrated superior methanation activity, attributed to its higher surface oxygen concentration, enhanced specific surface area, smaller Ni particle size, and abundant medium basic sites. The superior performance of the Y-promoted catalyst (5Y65Zr/30Ni) can be attributed to its effective combination of these key attributes. In contrast, the other catalysts display a less optimal balance of these properties. The La- and Pr-promoted catalysts showed moderate performance because their combination of surface area, basicity, and Ni dispersion was less ideal than that of the Y-promoted sample. The Sr-promoted catalyst served as a clear counterpoint, where a low surface area and large Ni particles led to poor performance, despite having a reasonable number of basic sites. The catalytic activity of a catalyst is not determined by a single factor but emerges from the synergistic effect of intrinsic physicochemical properties, such as surface structure, electronic configuration, and active site dispersion. These properties exist in a dynamic equilibrium, collectively governing reaction efficiency. These findings corroborate the findings in the literature and highlight the importance of optimizing these structural features to develop effective catalysts for CO₂ methanation. 5 Conclusion In this study, the effects of different promoters Y, La, Sr, and Pr on inverse ZrO₂/Ni catalysts for CO₂ methanation were comprehensively investigated, demonstrating that promoters (Y, La, Sr, Pr) critically tailor the electronic, structural, and mechanistic properties of inverse ZrO₂/Ni catalysts. The methanation activity of these catalysts directly correlates with the tunable physicochemical properties. The superior catalytic activity of the Y-promoted catalyst compared to all tested catalyst could be attributed to its increased specific surface area and the presence of more medium basic sites on the surface, which facilitate the adsorption and activation of CO2. In addition, the smallest Ni crystallite sizes on 5Y65Zr/30Ni highlights the importance of maintaining a high Ni dispersion for optimal catalytic performance. The highest ratio of surface oxygen enhanced the activation of CO₂ molecules, facilitating the initial steps of CO₂ methanation. These findings contribute to a better understanding of the structure - activity relationships in inverse ZrO₂/Ni catalysts with different additives, paving the way for the design of more efficient CO₂ methanation catalysts. coredata.dc:description: CO2 methanation reaction is a promising approach for both CO2 utilization and hydrogen storage, leveraging hydrogen produced from renewable energy sources to mitigate the energy crisis. Inverse ZrO₂/Ni catalysts promoted with Y, La, Sr, and Pr were synthesized and evaluated for CO₂ methanation. The impact of these promoters on the structure, properties, and catalytic performance of inverse ZrO₂/Ni catalyst was systematically investigated. A comprehensive suite of characterization techniques, including XRD, BET, H₂-TPR, CO₂-TPD, TEM, HRTEM, EDX-Mapping, and quasi in-situ XPS, was employed to elucidate the relationship between the physicochemical properties of the catalysts and their CO₂ methanation catalytic performance. 5Y65Zr/30Ni catalyst exhibited superior methanation activity compared with other catalysts, which was correlated with its enhanced specific surface area, a high concentration of medium basic sites facilitating CO₂ adsorption and activation, a high surface oxygen ratio, and optimal Ni dispersion achieved through minimized Ni crystallite size. These findings demonstrated that the strategic incorporation of promoters allowed for precise tailoring of inverse ZrO₂/Ni catalyst properties, providing valuable insights for the rational design of highly efficient CO₂ methanation catalysts.
